bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, March 8, 1941

div1.p: Hench wants Cooke to look over his report to prove the actual location of Camp Lazear. The report will be presented to Ramos in Cuba. Hench requests that Cooke write to Ramos if he supports Hench's claim.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, March 8, 1941
div1.p:
I believe you know of my attempts to prove the true location of Camp
Lazear in Havana. I have finally finished my report to Dr. Ramos and must send
it off to him next week. Before doing so, I am most anxious to have you look it
over. Our machine would only make four copies. I sent one each to General Kean and
General Truby and have just received their complete approval of it. Other copies
I sent to Havana, to Senora Rojas and to Mr. Moran. I expect these back the first
of the week. Would it be at all possible for you to look this over at your very
at
earliest convenience and send me airmail (stamped folder enclosed) back to me with
your comments and corrections? If you believe my evidence is valid, would you be
willing to write a note addressed to His Excellency, Dr. Domingo Ramos, Minister of
National Defense, Havana, Cuba, and enclose a letter for me to take to him with my
report. I cannot expect you to vouch for every word I have said, but if you believe
that I have in general correctly located Camp Lazear and correctly identified what
went on at the place now falsely marked Camp Lazear, a general statement to that
effect I am sure will be most helpful. Please mention your connection with the yellow
fever experiments and that you spent twenty-one nights in Building No. 1. That will
serve to identify you completely.

I have much more to write you, but cannot do it now. I must send this
report to Dr. Ramos next week. I leave here on March 21, with my family, for
Palm Beach (Villa Atlantique Hotel) and will go to Havana on or about the 27th
for five or six days. I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your help.

closer.seg:
P. S. I enclose a copy of Gen. Truby's letter about my report.
P. S. H.
